Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Host-Country Financial Development and Multinational Activity
L. Kamran Bilir Davin Chor
Wisconsin NUS
Kalina Manova
Oxford, Stanford and NBER
2-3 Jun 2016
ADB Conference on Economic Development
University of Hong Kong
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity

Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Motivation and Introduction
(cid:73) Multinationals (MNCs) today manage complex global operations that
serve multiple markets:
On average, US aﬃliates abroad sell 75% of their output in the host
country, ship 7% back to the US, and 18% to other countries.
(cid:73) This blends features of three FDI motives that the literature has
traditionally treated in isolation:
(cid:73) Horizontal: localsalestothehost-countrymarket
(cid:73) Vertical: aﬃliateexportsofintermediateinputs
(cid:73) Export-platform: aﬃliateexportsofﬁnalgoodstothird-countrymarkets
(cid:73) Above stylized fact suggests that reality is much more complex.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 2/33

Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Motivation and Introduction (cont.)
Pattern of MNC production and sales speaks to policy questions such as:
(cid:73) How do host-country conditions aﬀect MNCs’ entry and sales decisions?
(cid:73) How do MNC aﬃliates and local ﬁrms aﬀect each other?
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 3/33

Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Motivation and Introduction (cont.)
Pattern of MNC production and sales speaks to policy questions such as:
(cid:73) How do host-country conditions aﬀect MNCs’ entry and sales decisions?
(cid:73) How do MNC aﬃliates and local ﬁrms aﬀect each other?
This paper:
(cid:73) Studies how host-country ﬁnancial development aﬀects US multinational
activity abroad, in terms of:
(cid:73) NumberofUSaﬃliates
(cid:73) Levelsofaﬃliatesales: Intotal,aswellastothelocal,USandthird-country
markets
(cid:73) Sharesofaﬃliatesales: Tothelocal,USandthird-countrymarkets
(cid:73) Jointly, these patterns are consistent with two eﬀects of host-country
ﬁnancial development: (i) Competition eﬀect; and (ii) Financing eﬀect.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 3/33

3. However, at the individual aﬃliate level, sales to the local market ↓,
whereas sales to the US and third-country markets ↑.
4. In terms of shares: Share of aﬃliate sales to the local market ↓, whereas
shares of return sales to the US and export-platform sales to third-country
markets ↑. (Bothattheaggregateandindividualaﬃliatelevels.)
5. (Eﬀectontheshareofplatformsalesislargerthanthatontheshareofreturn
salestotheUS.)
Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Overview: Findings
We use the comprehensive and conﬁdential BEA data on the operations of US
multinationals abroad, 1989-2009.
Better ﬁnancial development in the FDI host country associated with:
1. A larger number of aﬃliates.
2. Higher levels of aggregate aﬃliate sales to the local, US and third-country
markets.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 4/33

Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Overview: Findings
We use the comprehensive and conﬁdential BEA data on the operations of US
multinationals abroad, 1989-2009.
Better ﬁnancial development in the FDI host country associated with:
1. A larger number of aﬃliates.
2. Higher levels of aggregate aﬃliate sales to the local, US and third-country
markets.
3. However, at the individual aﬃliate level, sales to the local market ↓,
whereas sales to the US and third-country markets ↑.
4. In terms of shares: Share of aﬃliate sales to the local market ↓, whereas
shares of return sales to the US and export-platform sales to third-country
markets ↑. (Bothattheaggregateandindividualaﬃliatelevels.)
5. (Eﬀectontheshareofplatformsalesislargerthanthatontheshareofreturn
salestotheUS.)
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 4/33

Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Overview: Findings (cont.)
Establish these ﬁndings in a range of speciﬁcations:
(cid:73) Estimating oﬀ the cross-country variation in ﬁnancial development.
(cid:73) Further exploiting cross-industry variation:
Stronger eﬀects in industries with a greater dependence on external
ﬁnance (Rajan and Zingales 1998)
(cid:73) Subsuming unobserved MNC characteristics with parent ﬁrm ﬁxed eﬀects
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 5/33

Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Overview: Findings (cont.)
Rationalize these patterns through a combination of two forces:
(i) Competition eﬀect:
Financialdevelopmentinthehostcountrypromotesentryofdomesticﬁrms
⇒ Localmarketbecomesmorecompetitive
⇒ MNCaﬃliatesorienttheirsalesawayfromservingthelocalmarket,towards
othermarketsinstead. (Matchingfacts3and4.)
(ii) Financing eﬀect:
IfMNCsrelyonhost-countryﬁnancing...
⇒ FinancialdevelopmentinthehostcountryfacilitatesentryofmoreMNC
aﬃliates(extensivemargin)
⇒ Intheaggregate,saleslevelstoallthreemarketsincrease. (Matchingfacts
1and2.)
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 6/33

Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Related Literature
1. Eﬀects of credit constraints on economic activity and trade:
(RajanandZingales1998,Aghionetal.2007,AmitiandWeinstein2011,Manova2013,...)
2. Host-country ﬁnancial conditions and multinational activity:
(Desaietal.2004,2008,FeinbergandPhillips2004,Manovaetal.2009,Bustos2007,
Antr`asetal.2009,CarluccioandFally2012)
3. Complex FDI strategies:
(Yeaple2003,Helpmanetal.2004,Grossmanetal.2006,MarkusenandVenables2007,
Ekholmetal.2007,Irarrazabaletal.2012,Ramondoetal.2012,Ramondoand
Rodriguez-Clare2013,Arkolakisetal.2012,Tintelnot2012)
4. Interaction between foreign aﬃliates and domestic ﬁrms:
(AitkenandHarrison1999,DeBackerandSleuwaegen2003,Alfaroetal.2004,Javorcikand
Spatareanu2009,Arnoldetal.2011)
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 7/33

Introduction Sketchofasetup
TheoreticalMechanisms TheCompetitionEﬀect
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad TheFinancingEﬀect
Setting
Consider a FDI host economy where:
(cid:73) There are two types of production entities: (i) domestic ﬁrms; and (ii)
MNC aﬃliates
(cid:73) Each ﬁrm/aﬃliate produces a distinct diﬀerentiated variety
Think: FirmheterogeneityalaMelitz(2003),HMY(2004)
(cid:73) Varieties are substitutes in consumption
(cid:73) A separate entry margin for both domestic ﬁrms and MNC aﬃliates
(cid:73) MNC aﬃliates in particular face a decision over how much to sell in the
host (HOR(a)), home (RET(a)), and third-country markets (PLA(a)).
(Note: Seethepaperforaformalizationinastylizedthree-countrysetting.)
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 9/33

Introduction Sketchofasetup
TheoreticalMechanisms TheCompetitionEﬀect
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad TheFinancingEﬀect
Credit constraints in the host country
(cid:73) Assume domestic ﬁrms need external ﬁnance for the ﬁxed cost of
operations in each period.
(cid:73) In the presence of ﬁnancing frictions: A margin of ﬁrms denied access to
credit, e.g., due to an inability to credibly commit to repayment.
(cid:73) Improvements in host-country ﬁnancial development therefore facilitate
entry by these domestic ﬁrms.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 11/33

Introduction Sketchofasetup
TheoreticalMechanisms TheCompetitionEﬀect
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad TheFinancingEﬀect
Empirical Hypotheses
Competition Eﬀect: Improved ﬁnancial development in the host country
induces entry of domestic ﬁrms
⇒ Increased competition in the host market
⇒ MNCs re-orient sales away from the local market towards other markets.
⇒ A decrease in each individual aﬃliate’s horizontal sales, both in levels and
in shares; converse response for return and platform sales.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 12/33

Introduction Sketchofasetup
TheoreticalMechanisms TheCompetitionEﬀect
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad TheFinancingEﬀect
Empirical Hypotheses
Competition Eﬀect: Improved ﬁnancial development in the host country
induces entry of domestic ﬁrms
⇒ Increased competition in the host market
⇒ MNCs re-orient sales away from the local market towards other markets.
⇒ A decrease in each individual aﬃliate’s horizontal sales, both in levels and
in shares; converse response for return and platform sales.
Hypothesis
When only the competition eﬀect is operative, better host-country ﬁnancial
development is associated at the level of the individual aﬃliate with:
(i) a decrease in HOR(a), an increase in PLA(a), and an increase in RET(a);
as well as
(ii) a decrease in HOR(a), an increase in PLA(a), and an increase in RET(a).
TOT(a) TOT(a) TOT(a)
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 12/33

Introduction Sketchofasetup
TheoreticalMechanisms TheCompetitionEﬀect
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad TheFinancingEﬀect
Empirical Hypotheses
Competition Eﬀect: Improved ﬁnancial development in the host country
induces entry of domestic ﬁrms
⇒ Increased competition in the host market
⇒ MNCs re-orient sales away from the local market towards other markets.
⇒ A decrease in each individual aﬃliate’s horizontal sales, both in levels and
in shares; converse response for return and platform sales.
However:
(cid:73) A more competitive host-country market would prompt exit by some MNC
aﬃliates.
(cid:73) If this extensive margin adjustment is suﬃciently large, aggregate aﬃliate
sales to all three destinations would decline.
(cid:73) Upshot: Competition eﬀect alone is not suﬃcient to fully rationalize the
patterns in the data.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 12/33

Introduction Sketchofasetup
TheoreticalMechanisms TheCompetitionEﬀect
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad TheFinancingEﬀect
Introducing the ﬁnancing eﬀect
Well-documented that MNCs seek host-country ﬁnancing:
(cid:73) Feinberg and Phillips (2004): About two-thirds of US MNC aﬃliate debt
comes from local borrowing
(cid:73) Independently veriﬁed this in the 1999 and 2004 benchmark BEA surveys.
(cid:73) Moreover: Desai et al. (2004) and Antr`as et al. (2009) show that the
share of local vs parent ﬁnancing obtained by aﬃliates responds to
host-country ﬁnancial development.
(cid:73) While parent ﬁrms clearly also raise ﬁnance in the home country...
... Host-country ﬁnancing is still necessary, e.g., if there are transactions
costs associated with moving funds across borders, or if home-country
creditors cannot eﬀectively monitor aﬃliate activity abroad.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 13/33

Introduction Sketchofasetup
TheoreticalMechanisms TheCompetitionEﬀect
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad TheFinancingEﬀect
Empirical Hypotheses (cont.)
Financing Eﬀect: More aﬃliates enter as credit constraints are alleviated
⇒ Aggregate levels of MNC activity increase on the extensive margin.
(cid:73) But: Competition eﬀect remains relevant for new and surviving aﬃliates
on the intensive margin.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 14/33

Introduction Sketchofasetup
TheoreticalMechanisms TheCompetitionEﬀect
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad TheFinancingEﬀect
Empirical Hypotheses (cont.)
Financing Eﬀect: More aﬃliates enter as credit constraints are alleviated
⇒ Aggregate levels of MNC activity increase on the extensive margin.
(cid:73) But: Competition eﬀect remains relevant for new and surviving aﬃliates
on the intensive margin.
Hypothesis
When both the competition and ﬁnancing eﬀects are present, the responses to
improved host-country ﬁnancial development at the individual aﬃliate level are
similar. Moreover, aggregating across aﬃliates in the host country, if the
ﬁnancing eﬀect is suﬃciently strong, one observes:
(i) an increase in the number of aﬃliates;
(ii) an increase in HOR, PLA, RET, and TOT; as well as
(iii) a decrease in HOR, an increase in PLA, and an increase in RET.
TOT TOT TOT
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 14/33

Second estimating equation
Further exploit cross-sectoral variation:
MNC =α+βFD +γFD ×EFD +ΓX +ϕ +ϕ +ε . (2)
ikt it it k it k t ikt
(cid:73) EFD : Share of capital expenditures not ﬁnanced by internal cash ﬂow
k
(cid:73) Rajan and Zingales (1998) argue that this is an inherent and plausibly
exogenous feature of industries, determined by technological factors
(cid:73) Isolates the role of the ﬁnancing mechanism: To rule out that FD may be
it
proxying for other forms of institutional reform.
(cid:73) Calculated from Compustat: Median ﬁrm, between 1996-2005.
(cid:73) AdvantagesofusingUSdata: Orthogonaltohost-countryoutcomes; results
valid insofar as EFD is a sectoral characteristic with a stable rank-ordering
across countries.

of US global MNC sales.

Introduction EmpiricalspeciﬁcationandData
TheoreticalMechanisms BaselineFindings
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad AdditionalChecks
Size of eﬀects: Aggregate multinational activity
For a one std dev increase in private credit, get on average:
(cid:73) a 10.6% increase in the number of MNC aﬃliates
(cid:73) a 17.4% increase in aggregate aﬃliate sales
(cid:73) a 2.5 percentage-point decrease in the local sales share; a 1 and 1.5
percentage-point increase in the return sales share to the US and the
platform sales share respectively.
Eﬀects are bigger in more external ﬁnance dependent industries:
(cid:73) Eﬀect on number of aﬃliates is 4.3% higher...
(cid:73) Eﬀect on aggregate aﬃliate sales is 10.2% higher...
... at the 75th relative to the 25th percentile industry.
Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 24/33

Bilir,Chor,Manova Host-CountryFinancialDevelopmentandMultinationalActivity 32/33

Introduction
TheoreticalMechanisms
EvidencefromUSMultinationalActivityAbroad
Conclusion
(cid:73) Host-country ﬁnancial development systematically inﬂuences the structure
of multinational activity:
(cid:73) AnincreaseinMNCaﬃliatepresence,intermsofnumbersandaggregate
saleslevels
(cid:73) Butalso: Triggersreallocationsinthecompositionofaﬃliatesales.
Horizontalmotivesbecomelessimportant,relativetoreturnandplatform
exports.
(cid:73) Consistent with the presence of two eﬀects:
(cid:73) Competitioneﬀect: EntryoflocalﬁrmsleadsMNCstoorienttheirglobal
salesawayfromthehostmarket.
(cid:73) Financingeﬀect: Entryofaﬃliatesraisesmultinationalactivityinthe
aggregate.
(cid:73) Scope to examine in more detail the interaction between MNC aﬃliates
and host ﬁrms in local ﬁnancial markets. To better understand how local
conditions aﬀect the nature of global supply chain activity.
